verses.text: After this, Jesus went around in Galilee, purposely staying away from Judea because the Jews there were waiting to take his life.
But when the Jewish Feast of Tabernacles was near,

rsbNotes.title: John 7:2
rsbNotes.text: 7:2 Feast of Booths. The longest festival of the Jewish year (lasting seven days), this feast followed the Jewish New Year and the Day of Atonement (Yom Kippur, Lev. 23; Deut. 16). It was a celebration of God’s gracious provision for the Israelites in the wilderness and the completion of the year’s harvest. There was a ceremonial water-drawing (commemorating the provision of water in the wilderness, Num. 20:2–13) and a lamp-lighting ritual. The first of these ceremonies provides the setting for Jesus’ proclamation in vv. 37, 38, the second for His statement in 8:12.

verses.text: Jesus' brothers said to him, "You ought to leave here and go to Judea, so that your disciples may see the miracles you do.
No one who wants to become a public figure acts in secret. Since you are doing these things, show yourself to the world."
For even his own brothers did not believe in him.

rsbNotes.title: John 7:3, 5, 10
rsbNotes.text: 7:3, 5, 10 his brothers. Cf. 2:12; Matt. 12:46. Some of the brothers later believed in Jesus (Acts 1:14).

verses.text: Therefore Jesus told them, "The right time for me has not yet come; for you any time is right.

rsbNotes.title: John 7:6
rsbNotes.text: 7:6 My time. See vv. 8, 30; 2:4; 8:20; 12:23; 13:1; 17:1; Matt. 26:18; Mark 14:41. Such passages show the concern of Jesus to conform to God’s schedule.

verses.text: The world cannot hate you, but it hates me because I testify that what it does is evil.

rsbNotes.title: John 7:7
rsbNotes.text:
7:7 The world. Humanity in its opposition to God and His purpose.

evil. Evildoers resent being unmasked by the good (3:19, 20).

verses.text: You go to the Feast. I am not yet going up to this Feast, because for me the right time has not yet come."
Having said this, he stayed in Galilee.
However, after his brothers had left for the Feast, he went also, not publicly, but in secret.
Now at the Feast the Jews were watching for him and asking, "Where is that man?"
Among the crowds there was widespread whispering about him. Some said, "He is a good man."

rsbNotes.title: John 7:8
rsbNotes.text: 7:8 I am not going up to this feast. Jesus does indeed later go to the Feast. His brothers have asked Him to present Himself openly to the crowds. But Jesus asserts that He is “not” yet ready to appear in such a public way.

verses.text: Others replied, "No, he deceives the people." But no one would say anything publicly about him for fear of the Jews.
Not until halfway through the Feast did Jesus go up to the temple courts and begin to teach.

rsbNotes.title: John 7:13
rsbNotes.text: 7:13 for fear of the Jews. This is not a reference to all those who were natural descendants of Abraham. Rather, the term refers to Jewish leaders and officials who were hostile toward Jesus.

verses.text: The Jews were amazed and asked, "How did this man get such learning without having studied?"

rsbNotes.title: John 7:15
rsbNotes.text: 7:15 has never studied. Jesus was not known to have been taught by any rabbi, yet His knowledge and wisdom astounded those who heard Him (cf. 3:2; Matt. 7:28; Luke 2:47).

verses.text: Jesus answered, "My teaching is not my own. It comes from him who sent me.

rsbNotes.title: John 7:16
rsbNotes.text: 7:16 his who sent me. Jesus indicates the source of His teaching. His message is not original with Himself but comes from His Father.

verses.text: If anyone chooses to do God's will, he will find out whether my teaching comes from God or whether I speak on my own.

rsbNotes.title: John 7:17
rsbNotes.text: 7:17 will know. A true perception of the divine nature of Christ’s teaching is granted to those who earnestly desire to do God’s will (Ps. 25:14).

verses.text: He who speaks on his own does so to gain honor for himself, but he who works for the honor of the one who sent him is a man of truth; there is nothing false about him.

rsbNotes.title: John 7:18
rsbNotes.text: 7:18 on his own authority. A contrast is established between self-seeking messengers and Jesus, whose guiding principle is to be true to His mission (12:49). See 1:14, 17; 14:6; 18:37; 2 Cor. 11:10; Rev. 3:7, 14; 19:11—passages where Christ and His message are identified with truth. This is also said of God the Father (7:28; 8:26; 17:3; Ps. 31:5; Is. 65:16; Rom. 3:4; 1 Thess. 1:9; 1 John 5:20; Rev. 6:10; 15:3; 16:7) and of the Holy Spirit (14:17; 15:26; 16:13; 1 John 4:6; 5:6). The same applies to the Scripture and apostolic preaching (17:17; Ps. 119:30, 43, 138, 142, 151, 160; Eph. 1:13; Col. 1:5; 2 Tim. 2:15; James 1:18). This is in sharp contrast with Satan who is “a liar” (8:44).

verses.text: Has not Moses given you the law? Yet not one of you keeps the law. Why are you trying to kill me?"

rsbNotes.title: John 7:19
rsbNotes.text: 7:19 Moses . . . the law. The blessing of having received the law as the revelation of God’s will (cf. Ps. 103:7; Rom. 3:2; 9:4) becomes a bane through disobedience (Rom. 7:7–12).

verses.text: "You are demon-possessed," the crowd answered. "Who is trying to kill you?"

rsbNotes.title: John 7:20
rsbNotes.text: 7:20 have a demon. Compare 8:48–52; 10:19–20; Matt. 12:24.

verses.text: Jesus said to them, "I did one miracle, and you are all astonished.

rsbNotes.title: John 7:21
rsbNotes.text: 7:21 I did one deed. Jesus refers to the one deed He had done in their region, the healing of the lame man (5:1–15).

verses.text: Yet, because Moses gave you circumcision (though actually it did not come from Moses, but from the patriarchs), you circumcise a child on the Sabbath.

rsbNotes.title: John 7:22
rsbNotes.text: 7:22 circumcision. Circumcision was prescribed in the law of Moses (Lev. 12:3), but it was previously instituted by God in the days of Abraham (Gen. 17:10–14). The regulation that it had to be performed on the eighth day was commonly regarded as taking precedence over the law of rest on the Sabbath.

verses.text: Now if a child can be circumcised on the Sabbath so that the law of Moses may not be broken, why are you angry with me for healing the whole man on the Sabbath?
Stop judging by mere appearances, and make a right judgment."
At that point some of the people of Jerusalem began to ask, "Isn't this the man they are trying to kill?
Here he is, speaking publicly, and they are not saying a word to him. Have the authorities really concluded that he is the Christ?

rsbNotes.title: John 7:23
rsbNotes.text: 7:23 whole body well. Jesus calls attention to the inconsistency of His accusers. There were a number of activities permitted on the Sabbath, including circumcision. He compares these activities with the work of healing.

verses.text: But we know where this man is from; when the Christ comes, no one will know where he is from."
Then Jesus, still teaching in the temple courts, cried out, "Yes, you know me, and you know where I am from. I am not here on my own, but he who sent me is true. You do not know him,
but I know him because I am from him and he sent me."

rsbNotes.title: John 7:27
rsbNotes.text: 7:27 we know where this man comes from. The people knew that Jesus was from Galilee (vv. 41, 52), and this seemed to conflict with the prevailing view that the Messiah would come from Bethlehem (v. 42; Matt. 2:5, 6) or that His origin would be unknown. Jesus in response points to His divine origin rather than an earthly location. In failing to acknowledge His divine mission they showed their ignorance of God’s plan, in spite of the miracles, which were proof of God’s endorsement (v. 31).

verses.text: At this they tried to seize him, but no one laid a hand on him, because his time had not yet come.

rsbNotes.title: John 7:30
rsbNotes.text: 7:30 they were seeking to arrest him. The plots against Christ’s life could not succeed until God’s own time had come.
